37722013.review:
Lucid9 is an underrated original English visual novel (OEVN) which appeals brilliantly to both new and seasoned visual novel players. Its characters, story and music are all top notch, and for the very low price of £0.00 you should really give it a go.

This review will not contain spoilers - as a result, some truths may be slightly bent to inform you without giving too much away.

TL;DR:
Story: 10/10
Characters: 9/10
Visuals: 9/10
Music & Sound: 10/10
Verdict: It's free and only 15 hours long, go play it already!

[h1]Story - 10/10[/h1]

In Lucid9 you play Yama, a high school student enrolled in a private Japanese academy for wealthy kids. At the beginning of the new school year, students start to go missing. Meanwhile a freelance detective approaches you in the hope of solving what the police cannot - how and why these disappearances are taking place.

The game is around 15 hours long, and mainly focuses on the mystery at hand while also fleshing out each character (especially Yama and his past). The story is executed very well, building suspense while keeping the identity of the perpetrator hidden until the very end, but there are definitely enough clues to figure it out yourself if you pay attention. Yama's shaky past and his psycholigical problems that arise from it make the story much more interesting later on. There is also a fair amount of time spent on the daily life of Yama and his friends, but no scene is superflous - they all help build the character of the main cast and their relationship to Yama and each other.

There is one good ending, with many bad endings depending on your choices in the final stages of the game. Although you can gain favour with four characters, Lucid9 isn't a dating sim - Rui is always the 'main girl' of the story and the other characters acknowledge this very early on. This helps focus the spotlight on her, which I think works in the game's favour. The deduction sequences are also fun and don't feel forced at all. Overall the story and how it was presented was fantastic.

[h1]Characters - 9/10[/h1]

Despite there being loads of characters to cram into a very short story, Lucid9 pulls it off perfectly. Firstly, Yama's character is not that of a generic protagonist - he can be lazy and harsh but this makes his character much more interesting. His development is timed well and progresses steadily throughout. His psychological problems and his past are relevant and didn't feel like a gimmick to liven up the story. The other four non-romance characters - Masato, Yukari, Ryouta and Shigure - are also developed, albeit much less. I found Yukari's development to be one of the most interesting in any story, and each character definitely has their own unique charm and story (even if they can sometimes be a bit annoying).

The four girls are also very unique, and you will definitely be enjoying the scenes with at least one of them. I especially liked the developing relationships with Airi and Elizabeth - they felt natural and well written. Akira's scenes are full of energy, Misaki's are sensible and relaxing, Lizzie's are sharp-witted and funny, and Airi's are very calming. Each character's theme was also very well crafted. Finally, Rui's character didn't have that much development and was pretty generic, but she did not bring the rest down at all. I personally found Rui and Misaki to have the weakest characterisation and development - hopefully this is remedied in the upcoming sequel, which should have separate routes per character.

Side note: As someone who has participated in several student drama groups before, I was very happy to see how accurate they made the drama club at the academy! I really got into the two scenes set there and Akira, while slightly over the top, was someone whose escapism I could somewhat relate to.

[h1]Visuals - 9/10[/h1]

The visuals in this game are amazing. There was clearly a lot of effort put into the character sprites, backgrounds and CGs. The style is distinct, but not enough to  be jarring. The happy scenes were bright and cheerful and the violent scenes were gory in all their glory. There was a perfect mix of light and heavy - they definitely didn't keep it PG when it came to the violence. However, I felt that in a few CGs the faces were strangely proportioned and some backgrounds seemed to be intentionally blurred.

Note also that there is no sexual content, although due to the graphic nature of some scenes and some disturbing scenes and themes I would recommend not giving this game to someone under 12 years old (also, the deduction sequences would go right over their head).

[h1]Music & Sound - 10/10[/h1]

The music in this game is absolutely exceptional. The generic happy/sad/emotional/mystery themes were great, but what really stood out for me was the character themes. Each character's theme is perfectly suited from them, from Airi's music box and Elizabeth's piano to Shigure's mysterious theme with sirens in the background and Akira's upbeat and energetic melody. The other two outstanding tracks were the title theme, and one other theme called 'Depths' that plays during certain scenes. Depths in particular is a real emotion inducer in context, and it works amazingly.

Lucid9 has no voice acting, although an English voice pack is in the works. Also, the soundtrack can be downloaded for free from Steam (it will appear as a .zip in the game directory).

Highlights of the OST:

What can I say? This was my very first visual novel that I was determined to read from the start. The poor male protagonist has his work cut out for him, if he wasnt heading for a nuthouse already, he surly will be in one by the end of this story. I finished this visual novel ages ago however never wrote a review for it, so here we go. I'll try not to spoil the story too much!

My pros, cons and overall review.

[b] Pros: [/b]
- Storyline. It has so many twists and turns that it even gets you as the reader thinking what's gonna happen next, who is it? It gets you on the edge of your seat, you're right there with the group of friends solving the mystery together. It's spectacular!
- Character Development. The charaters were definitely well written along with some sort of backstory but it's just enough to understand the suspicions of the protagonist as well as his friendships with the other characters.
- Music. the music is done well, it really sets the mood. Happy, sad, sinister, you name it and it's there making you feel the same dread as the protagonist.
- Art Design. Magnificently drawn, characters, backgrounds and pictures. They're nicely done for such a dark story.
- Routes/Story Length. The story is nice and long, a good amount of hours will go into reading and there aren't any drastic choices until the end so don't worry about messing up half way and needing to restart. You'll be ok. Even the ending is nice and long and it gives a semi-heartwarming "good" ending although dont expect it to last very long.

[b] Cons: [/b]
- Routes. There are SO many routes so you'd be spending hours upon hours trying to get them all (especially if you want the achievements).
- Difficulty. This visual novel is difficult to get by without a guide although I always use a guide for any visual novel I read as I like to get the best possible ending first before getting the bad endings. I did attempt this without a guide at first but alas, it wasn't easy especially with the puzzles you have to solve. Although the puzzles were still fun, even with a guide.
- No Romance. I'm a huge sucker for a good romance but amidst all the death and despair there isnt a single romance going on. We know 1 of the protagonist's friends loves him however they never go on a date, kiss, talk about it or anything. It's only implied by actions made and nothing comes of it (considering the "good" ending, I suppose I see why but still).
- Language. This story uses a lot of "big words" to put it simply, I dont consider this to be a con for me but some may consider it as such so I shall place it here for readers notice.

[b] Overall: [/b]
This was an amazing visual novel, although not a romantic one it definitely didn't fail at being a dark mystery visual novel. The sinister elements, the happy times, the twists and turns and the all out performance was fanatastic. For my first visual novel, I do highly recommend this read, you WON'T be disappointed in the slightest.

Lucid9 was a very fun and enjoyable experience for me. Seeing that this game had impressive ratings and was for free, I instantly installed it to my computer. It is somewhat really hard to believe that something of this polish is actually for free in the market, especially when most visual novels that are for free tend to be more of low quality. 

The story of Lucid9 starts rather slow, presenting its cast of characters and their dynamics. Due to this, the story has a large focus on showing each character’s personal history, life circumstances, and how they react to the mysterious murders that surround them which is the focus of the plot. It also knows how and when to give the details of its story which helps in keeping you intrigued and interested all the way to its climax. It also can get crazy and a bit dark if you aren’t prepared.

Due to the story of Lucid9 focusing more on its characters, it is quite important that the character holds up well and can keep you invested in them. Each individual character appears to have their own past and outlook in their current situation that despite being a tad bit generic was still rather enjoyable. Throughout the course of my whole experience with its characters and its story, I ended up being invested and caring for them thanks to their natural, likeable and expressive dialogue.

For a free visual novel, Lucid9 actually has some really delightful visuals. It might sometimes look a bit off in some areas of the game, but for the most part they do the job right. The music really struck accord with me. With some lively music for high school life and some suspenseful music for its darker scenes, it really did a nice job in setting the tone and mood which complemented each of its respective scenes. 

Overall, Lucid9 was a cool experience. It knows what it’s trying to do and does it very well in all aspects through its story, characters, visuals, and soundtrack. Just let yourself enjoy the experience which Lucid9 is trying to offer you and maybe you’ll have a very fun and enjoyable experience.  As I stated before at the beginning, it’s for free so there really isn’t anything to lose but a few hours of your life. 

I recommend that you give Lucid9: Inciting Incident a shot.

This is an absolutely fantastic game. It's as simple as that. Don't be fooled by the fact that it is free to play, it still stands head and shoulders above your baseline visual novel experience. If the patch for part 2 turns out to be as good as the original, then I'll be forced to meet the creators in person for a nice, firm handshake.

[b] There are only a few things worth warning you about, so I'll lay them out here: [/b]

Art assets. There aren't many. This is obviously a direct result of the budget, and I'm personally not upset about it in the slightest. This is just fair warning for what you can expect to see. I know we all want our waifus and waifu-talking-to locations to be great in number and look one-of-a-kind, but trust me, they're plenty distinctive in other ways. (This is also a good place to mention that this is not exactly a "waifu" game, if that is a problem for any of you degenerates)

You will feel emotions. Sad emotions. This isn't something I personally dislike at all, in fact it's part of what makes this VN experience so great in my opinion. Unfortunately, some of you suck! A few reactions that I've read indicate that tragedy bothers people, but for a pseudo-mystery pseudo-slice-of-life, it's absolutely appropriate. Just be prepared to be hit with some dark stuff!

I am writing this (and played this) before the release of the second part. If you are like me, then you have to go into this knowing that although the ending will absolutely feel like the ending to a legitimate, full game, you will most likely wish you could get into the next part of the story. Unless you are late to the party (HAHA, losers!), you will have to wait. it sucks, but don't let that stop you from playing the game we have now!

This last one almost goes without saying, since this is always a risk with VNs. the MC might not always do the things you wanted him to do, or think the things that you wanted him to think. This is mostly because he isn't just an empty vessel for us to project into. Not entirely, at least.

[b] Alright, now for the good part. This is BY NO MEANS a comprehensive list of the positives in this game. Nobody has the time to read that. These are my personal favorite little things that stood out and made this VN so cool to me: [/b]

Even though there are quirky weirdos, there is more or less a "real person" feel to your relationships with the cast. Now, I'll give you fair warning that the people themselves often have exaggerated elements, but I mean "real person" in the sense of how your character interacts with them. Even though they can be frustrating buttholes at times, that's how people are in the real world, too. You aren't always satisfied with what they say or do to you. You aren't always treated fairly. Not every female is gonna suck your donger (Sad, I know). You might have characters you hate, even though you really wanted to love them going in. And people annoy you with their jim-jams when you don't even wannna hear it! This might just be me, but a certain topic that few characters wouldn't shut up about was something that I had no interest in. At first I was a tad salty, but it isn't something that made the experience less enjoyable. Having conflict is important, and making the player salty isn't always a bad emotion to bring out.

GOVER MECHER IS A WORK OF ABSOLUTE FUCKING GENIUS

This is for the people that have played multiple VNs before. You can't take anything for granted. This game doesn't adhere to the unspoken rules set by other games in the genre. I can't tell you how many times I was groaning in anticipation for a plot point that was either cliche or too boring and unimaginative. I'm not saying that you won't ever be able to predict what's coming next (although I think a few twists may get you), but there will probably be times when people who've played these types of games before will think "I know what they're going to do with this, and I'm already disappointed." There may be a couple instances where you feel let down (I can't read minds), but if you have too many preconceptions then I can guarantee that they won't be met.

You get a bit of everything. As I mentioned before, this game has some "slice-of-life" mixed in with some "mystery," and the two parts are merged in a satisfying way. You get time for a light-hearted goof, and you get time for some spooks. This game has got it all.

Look here, kiddo. I know I told you that not every anime grill is gonna suckle on your ding-dong like in your dating-sims, but you made it this far, so here's the skinny on the situation. You will find the elusive "best grill" in this game. In fact, that's the best part of the mystery. You've gotta hunt for the best grill, and it won't be easy! You'll be saying to yourself "Oh MCMECHA, why couldn't your review just TELL me who the best grill is! I'm too foolish to find her on my own!" But you see, that's the fun part! It's not easy to find out who the best one is, because you'll want to jingle your jangles with more than one, if my playthrough is any indicator! They've all got strong points and weak points. Hell, I'm almost glad that you won't be able to choose Yahiko in part 2 just because the allure of GOVER MECHER would draw me away from the ladies!

All things considered, you seriously need to play this game. It's worth every minute of your time, and this VN deserves all of the support it can get from the fine people here on steam. So play the hell out of it and tell your friends. If you don't, I'll give ya a big smack on the head, y'hear?

Actually, I am not very familiar with the genre of visual novels. I tried some so far, both free and bought ones, but none of them was slightly thrilling. When I found this VN on steam, it really catched my attention due to its tremendously high rating. However, I was sceptical in the beginning.

Free? Plain artwork? No synchronisation? That sounds like a very cheap product. Not even worth my time. But hey, it's free. At least I can try it out.

And I was proven wrong. Goddamn wrong.

What catches your eyes immediately is the way the protagonist talks with the other characters. The verbal exchange of words and the endless witty remarks are absolutely hilarious and entertaining. If you are someone, who likes to reflect on new ways to express trivial things, likes to explore the borders of the spoken word or loves absurd dialogues, then I can assure thee undoubtely, this visually animated opus of modern literature will bestow great fortune on thee, little chap. (Note: If you liked the dialogues in the anime [b]"Bakemonogatari"[/b], you will surely love this one as well)

The main characters talks with every characters in a different way, depending on the situation and the story developed so far, thus creating a very vivid and immersive atmosphere. At some point, I really awaited conversations with specific characters eagerly, because you could rest assured, you will laugh like bloody hell with a cup of tea in your hand. [i]Cheerio, Miss Bennett![/i]

A vast cast of characters is introduced, everyone unique with their own traits and behaviour. Of course, some of them are the typical generic characters everyone knows from animes, but some had personalities I haven't seen before. But don't let the first impression fool you. Some of the characters (sadly not all) are much more complex than anticipated and reveal their depths of their character as the plot unravels (But do not expect too much depths!! You might brake your ankle!!). To my surprise, this VN also thematized psychology to an extent, that it was not ridiculously anymore and could be taken seriously. However, I must warn you again, that the theory of Sigmund Freud or Jung are not discussed in this VN, but a basic comprehension of psychology is crucial to the understanding of the protagonist's thought and behaviour.

The story itself is mainly a composition of dialogue, comedy, mystery, thriller, and a pinch of romance and masterly switches the atmosphere at any time. Last sentence was a hilarious joke and suddenly we are terrified by new informations. Additionally, the mood of the current situation is always perfectly captured by the background music. Whether a light-hearted tune or tensed melody, whether the music relaxes you or sends a chill down your spine, it amazingly fits well the whole time. As for the lenght of VN: Holy moly, it is fucking long. And I mean FUCKING long.

[u]Final words[/u]
+ great dialogue humour
+ diverse story telling
+ immersive atmosphere
+ matching soundtrack
+ interesting characters
+ FREE!!

- No controversial drama
- simple animations
- No seriously, if you are still reading this review, then you don't have any excuses to NOT play this free game!

[u]PS[/u]
If you liked the dialogues of this VN, you should really consider watching the anime [b]"Bakemonogatari"[/b].

Lucid9 is a decent game. Some might not think so much of it, some might think more, but I, for the most part, enjoy the story. The first time, that is. 

Although this is a positive review, I'm first going to point out one of more frustrating points of the game. To beat it and get all the achievements, you're going to have to go through it several times. Certainly, this can be shortened by saving at certain points, but you have to start from the beginning if you happen to miss anything early on. It may seem minor, but, as there are quite a few choices in the game regardless of relevance to the story, it can get rather tedious. 

Now, onto the overall review.

The art was very nice, as far as I'm concerned. It fit the story at most points, though I think some of the characters were a tad plain. Yama, for instance. He's the one you play as, but nothing stands out beyond his yellow eyes. And the yellow eyes don't even really complement him. Other characters could also be seen in the same light. Beyond this, the art suited the game. The eyes did get on my nerves, though, and not just on Yama. Also, the characters look pretty... stunted? It makes them look like children, but that may just be the effect of me looking at them too long.

The characters don't just have their looks, though. A lot of them were also good in terms of character development. Some of them could have been done better, yes, but overall I think it worked out well. To name a few of the characters that fell short, there was Natsuki Tanaka, Masato Kurogane, and Rui Hayata. One of the characters, Akira Karube, did get on my nerves. Her personality has been done to hell and back in games all across the board. For a major character, however, she contributed very little to the story. Is this a negative or a positive?

Now, for the story itself... I really don't have many complaints here. I do think there should've been more hints along the way about what was really going on, and the player (reader?) ought to be able to figure out at least some of the story before it comes down to the big conclusion. It should also be worth more that the player/reader get close to certain people. At current, are there any benefits to learning about those around you? No. Is there anything relevant to the case? No. Why should you pursue other characters? Curiosity?

That being said, I did get a bit off-track there. The story is ambitious, I'll give you that, but I think it took too long to get it out there. Some scenes simply dragged on, like that carnival thing. Completely unecessary, that scene. It served no other purpose besides letting you learn some minor things about the main characters, and took too long to get past. There were other scenes like that scattered about, and it isn't very pleasant to go through them five or so times for an achievement or something of that sort.

I'm just going to slide this in since I kind of forgot about it, but the music wasn't bad. I liked the main title theme, but some of the other tracks were obviously overused. Others merely faded into the background. This aside, it wasn't terrible.

Lucid9 was one of my first visual novels, and was altogether memorable. It was altogether an enjoyable experience that I would recommend. You'll have to tolerate a few holes (maybe more than a few...), but it can be difficult to find any game without such things. Lucid9 definitely has problems, but it isn't a bad game.

[h1]Lucid9 : Inciting Incident[/h1]

Lucid9 est une histoire visuelle qui se passe en milieu scolaire mais dont la toile de fond est guidée par de mystérieuses et sombres disparitions. Vous incarnez Yama, étudiant cynique, sans passion ni ambition et roi de l’autodépréciation. L’histoire est vécue à travers les yeux de ce héro un peu ennuyant, le début est un peu comme une longue file d’attente qui risque de faire fuir les impatients et ceux qui ne sont pas amateurs de school Life/slice of life. On y découvre néanmoins les différents personnages qui sont intéressants, drôle pour certains et auquel on a pas de mal à s’attacher. Graphiquement c’est plutôt agréable à regarder, j’ai un peu moins accroché aux musiques (question de goût) même si certaines sont sympathiques.

Difficile à lire parfois sans un bon niveau d’anglais, j’ai mis plus de 30 heures mais j’imagine que les plus rapides peuvent mettre entre 10-15h.
Côté points négatifs, à part quelques longueurs et passages un peu ennuyant c’est surtout le fait que ce ne soit que la première partie de l’histoire qui est dérangeant. [b]Bilan : 8.2/10[/b]

30423295.review:
[i]Lucid9[/i] is a free to play visual novel set a fictional 2018 Japan. In this game you play as Yama, a lazy good-for-nothing with quite a few mental issues. A string of disappearances are happening, all of them students from the school Yama attends which is supposed to be highly secure. You’ll have to juggle your school and social life while trying to find out what’s happening to the students and who is doing it. Can you do it before someone you care for joins the list?

Unlike many people who found this story to be touching or sad, I found myself more indifferent and bored. The story drags on for a while, this due to the fact that our protagonist doesn’t actually actively care or do anything about the disappearances until over halfway through the game. While players are fully aware that something is wrong, we experience this through Yama’s eyes. A good chunk of the first game is spent just chatting with friends, taking tests and other mundane things, which is fine if this was a slice of life title. Putting that aside, the other reason why I found the game to drag on was Yama’s pretentious nature. His inner monologues are long, drawn out and reek of someone trying to sound smart but failing miserably. That being said, the characters besides Yama and Rui are enjoyable and I enjoyed the scenes where you interact and get to know them.

[list]
[*][b]Yama[/b] - Our hero of the story, a self-admitted loser who looks down on almost everyone. As a main character I found him utterly annoying. The game starts with making you wonder if he’s the killer or someone else is since Yama has “lapses.” These are when he blacks out but apparently can still move, talk and perform actions. He’s depressed, self-deprecating and puts up a wall to avoid showing the world how fragile he is. His best moments in the game is when he’s interacting with his friends and learning to understand them.
[*][b]Rui[/b] - The childhood best friend trope, she stands by Yama no matter what and tries her best to take care of him. She always defends him and knows most of his secrets, she’s also in love with him. Wow, go figure. The game is very adamant about pushing Yama and she together, despite him not really showing any interest. All of the character’s in the game push this and Rui refuses to confess because that’s what the trope calls for. I also found her annoying and how she was pushed upon Yama, though I did respect her dedication to him and believe she’d stay that way even if they don’t end up together.
[*][b]Misaki, Airi, Akira and Elizabeth[/b] - These are the other females in the game that go to school with Yama and Rui, Misaki is their childhood friend. Akira is Rui’s best friend who is also in love with Yama. Airi is a mysterious girl who is very quiet and Elizabeth is the smartest girl in the school who is probably also in love with Yama. The game lets your choose options with them, like call or text and even hang out. You can get to know each of them and doing so makes the game more well-rounded. Doing so also doesn’t matter, the game ends the same way so don’t expect a cute romance with any of them like I unfortunately did.
[*][b]Yahiko and Masato[/b] - Yama’s two male friends. Yahiko is a ball of fun and laughs who is also very naive. Masato is an incredibly smart jock who is very competitive. They help round out the circle of friends often offer most of the humor present in the story. They both care about Yama very much, however Masato greatly dislikes Yama’s laziness.
[*][b]Shigure and Mr. Ryouta[/b] - The two main adults in this game, Shigure is a private detective that hires Yama to be her assistant and opens his eyes to the rampant disappearances. She is snarky and at times quite rude but is a good addition to the story and helps move things along. Mr. Ryouta is the dorm manager at the school and quasi guidance counselor. He offers Yama support and an open ear while trying to motivate him to do better.
[/list]

Story aside, everything else about [i]Lucid9[/i] is fine. You use your mouse to play the game, though there are two points in which you will need a keyboard. You can click to progress the text or put it on auto and relax, there is also a skip feature to zoom past text you’ve already scene while trying to achieve other endings. The user interface is simple and offers all of the options needed for a visual novel such as the ability to hide text. One thing I did not like about the gameplay is how your choices mean very little. Other than failing the final steps against the villain your choices have no impact. Passing or failing tests is meaningless, getting to know a girl or not does nothing, you can’t end up with her and in any deduction sequence choosing the wrong answer will just lead you to try and pick a different one. The ending of the story is always bad and you can’t change it which I don’t mind but it can be a downer.

I really enjoyed the music in the game, it was cheerful when it needed to be and had great sad melodies as well. The music always fit the scenario. The game also has sound effects which were fine, though I found the phone ringing one annoying since there is at least once you don’t answer the phone right away because Yama is having yet another long inner monologue. The art is fine, I enjoyed it and the character models were cute. The game has superb CG art, even of the most unpleasant thing. My only complaint is that where weren’t more CG scenes. The game is rather long and I would have enjoyed seeing more of the lovely artwork.

I may sound critical of the game but did like it on some levels. While some things dragged on for a bit it did build up the feeling that slowly but surely Yama was losing everything around him and it was satisfying when he overcame this. This satisfaction is probably why the lack of any happy endings hurt so much because in the end it seemed like it was all for naught. The game is free so you’re not losing anything by giving [i]Lucid9[/i] a go, the developers promise more content in the future as well. For now you have Steam achievements and cards and an overall interesting experience for free.

30394378.review:
(English is not my mother tongue, so the text below may not fit the standarts set by Jane Austin, Charles Dickens or whoever is considered as an example of good English writing. Or even the standarts set by your school teacher.)

In brief: a really enjoyable visual novel with a few "it's-bugging-me" issues.

In not so brief. While I haven't played too many visual novels and I suppose that there might be some diversity there, most of the ones I played were basically about "choose a girl, collect enough love points and get your romantic ending (or possibly see her breaking and leaving or commiting suicide if you haven't got enough points)". It was somehow refreshing to play a VN that has you do something else. The beginning seemed quite boring - while the writing style itself was (and is) good, the contents itself were not that promising, and the only thing that was saving the day for me was the humor. I have to give the writers credit for this, I laughed like crazy at the "Yama imagines his possible future jobs" sequence. Despite that, some hours in the game, somewhere around the amusement park part i though like "just how much of all this slice of life is there in shis supposedly detective story". But then the things got better, much better. I absolutely enjoyed the whole "investigation in imagination" sequence (orchestrated really well, indeed), the writers did their best to make me doubt my theories even though they seemed quite solid, and the climax really gave me chills (while, I've got to say it, some choices seemed quite counter-intuitive). I also liked the many little flashbacks about the previously foreshadowed and then totally forgotten things during the revelation (when a gun on the wall shoots, it's really nice of the author to remind a forgetful reader like me that it has been hanging there in the first place). At the same time... Well, OK, I'm not going to talk about the ending I've seen until there will be the others. Or I will, in brief (some spoilers here)... Sometimes you feel that the ending, no matter how bad, is deserved, and you make it so with your own decisions, and sometimes you don't. Here, I didn't. It was kinda uncalled for. Absolutely uncalled for. But OK, let's wait for the next part and then see.

The music. I was going to call it "passable", but, if I think twice, it is better. It is definitely doing it's job in maintaining the athmosphere, and even if I didn't like the soundtrack in general as much as I liked the music of Everlasting Summer or Katawa Shoujo, still I really liked some particular tracks, and "Process of elimination" was just great, really contributing to the scenes it played in.

Also, as we're at it, solving puzzles was enjoyable. Quite a good way to make the player involved, maybe better than all the classic "say a compliment to the girl or stay silent" VN choices.

Can't say too much the visuals as I'm not an art expert. It seemed like there is too few CGs, but I suppose the backgrounds could have taken too much resources. As for the sprites, it could have really helped if, for example, when a character is said to wear a cat suit, actually have such sptite. As rare as these occasions are, if the visuals clearly contradict the written text, it is somehow damaging the thing they called a willing suspension of disbelief.

Speaking of which, the thing that annoyed me most. Dear creators, if you read it: if you have a Japanese setting, please, be consistent with it. A line like "No, cats don't speak English" doesn't make sense because, well, the characters are not speaking English! Even if the novel itself is written in English, it is set in Japan, the signs are in Japanese, the characters are Japanese, so the language they speak in-universe must obviously be Japanese. The same goes for the units of measurement. Even if the creators are English or American, and even if the majority of the audience are English or American, if the characters are Japanese, they use neither feet nor pounds, they should use the metric units. Anything else will look, I don't know, like a Japanese novel set in the US and featuring the American characters using koku or shaku instead of gallons and yards. Not the best idea.

The special effects, like transitions, are well done, and I have to especially praise those who made the phone calls and text message effects and the VR displays "interface". Really nice. The only thing I didn't like was how a character sprite leans closer whenever the said character is speaking. It seemed to me somehow distracting and not really necessary.

ALL IN ALL: some really good job the creators did, especially for a freeware product. I totally do not regret about the 20+ hours I spent playing, would really like to see any other visual novel from this developer and, should it be commercial, would not hesitate to pay for it, provided that it is of the same level of quality.

Pros:
* VERY well-written story and characters (that ending though! I want a sequel quick!)
* Dedection sections are very fun; the player gets to be the detective, unlike in Higurashi
* Free to play! This is totally a steal! Very much worth the time to go through!

* I'm probably one of the few to consider this a pro, but the lack of gratutious sexuality as is done so often in visual novels is very refreshing. Considerations:

29480174.review:
Outstanding Visual Novel: a free dark pyschological teen highschool dating serial killer suspense novel.

First and foremost, it's the wry self-aware writing that draws me in; it is supported by the typical VN backgrounds and character drawings, and a very effective soundtrack (35 titles) and sound effects, with some sparingly used visual effects. The pacing and building of suspense is top notch; there are several times where I thought the game was nearing its end only to draw me in and push me on some more. This goes on for hours, it's that big; which is very unusual in a free VN.

The game focuses on a group of eight protagonists: we get to know them, their backstory and character, and while the game is not afraid of re-using VN and anime tropes, it is aware of that and manages to not come off as clichéd throughout. It is here that the novel really shines: I was very interested to get to know these characters, and often seemed to know more about them than the narrator does. The crime mystery plot is also executed well. At the same time, this could never be the plot of a Disney movie: while there is a lot of (well-excuted) lightness, the game gets very dark at times, too.

It is not hard to choose those gameplay options that will result in uncovering most of the story elements, except for getting past the bad climax: remember to save when you get a phone call in the subway (you can right-click to access the menu from any screen) -- and you do need to get past it, the ending that follows is not a quick one. Apart from this episode, and a small section where the narrator perspective shifts to Riu (why was that even necessary?), story progression was smooth and kept me on edge.

Technically, this renPy game is well crafted and has all the features you'd expect: it runs windowed and works well on older systems.

If you like to read a good story, I can only imagine you discarding this game if you either have no tolerance for the high school dating sim tropes that this game employs in parts, or if it is too dark for you: you will find out about the latter in the first few minutes. Very much recommended.

29323807.review:
This is the first non-Gyakuten Saiban visual novel that I have finished. At first I did not know very well what to expect since the world of visual novels is something relatively new for me. But what I was looking for was an incredible and enthralling story through which visual novels are characteristic, and boy Lucid9 did not disappoint at all.


[h1][i][PLOT][/i][/h1]

The plot is incredibly well written in this visual novel, I didn't expect it to be so good. The development is one of its strongest points. The story gradually becomes darker, Madoka style. Most of the characters are very well written, each has a credible personality within the story, which makes them believable. Their relationships, the dialogues, everything is natural according to their personality. I came to feel affection for them, worry, hatred, sadness. I would give it a perfect rating at this point if it weren't for some minor elements of the plot that didn't totally convince me, and because the end didn't hit me as intended because of the multiple bad endings.


[h1][i][VISUALS][/i][/h1]

As for art, in general it is fine. It is not the best thing I have seen but it fulfills its role. The character portraits are fine, in fact there are some that I quite like. However, there are some that need a little more polishing to look good. On the other hand, the lack of variety of background images is often evident. Excessive reuse of these can lead to distraction if you don't have enough imagination. Another problem is that most of the CG scenes don't look that good. This is because in all these cases, the drawings of the characters are not well proportioned.


[h1][i][MUSIC & SOUND][/i][/h1]

The music in Lucid9 is gorgeous, easily one of the best video game soundtracks I've ever heard. Each theme is unique and brings tonality and emotion to the situation in which you find yourself. Sounds, on the other hand, don't stand out so much, they are simply there to add relevance to certain actions that happen in the story.


In conclusion, do I recommend Lucid9? Absolutely. If you are enthusiastic about good stories this is an assured recommendation. In fact this is a visual novel that I'd recommend to anyone who is remotely interested in visual novels. It's really worth it.

My rating is:  [b]8.0 / Very Good.[/b]

28972329.review:
There is one famous Japanese series that Lucid9 reminds me of a little: Higurashi. Both start off light-hearted and have their fair share of [strike]arguably[/strike] comical slice-of-life high school shenanigans, and both eventually take a much darker and more serious turn (although Lucid9 has no supernatural elements). This is not to say they are the same, but I wonder whether the creators were inspired by 07th Expansion's work.

I believe this comparison already sets the bar pretty high, and trust me, the game does not disappoint. Writing is very good and each character has a very distinct voice, filled with entertaining expressions and colourful vocabulary that get you through even the lengthiest calm/comedic moments (which I am personally not very fond of). The mystery parts are also well written and visual/sound effects work well with the narrative to convey a story that made my heart race and my eyes never deviate from the screen.

Another plus of this novel is the portrayal of mental illness. It is a central topic to the story and it is never portrayed in stereotypical or negative light, only realistic. I also enjoyed their use of dissociative disorder, which is hardly ever seen in media.

As for the cons, the main ones I'd list would be the length of comedic filler, the fact that some choices seem to serve no purpose but get achievements, and the character art. While most sprites look alright, others look strange and most CGs have issues, especially with proportions and facial angles. They are not [i]bad[/i], but definitely need some work.

Either way, I still recommend this and am very surprised to have stumbled upon such a good free VN [strike]I would've gladly paid for it, tbh[/strike]. Definitely looking forward to the next arc.

I’ve always been one for visual novels. Lucid9: Inciting Incident showed up in my queue, and it instantly piqued my interest. I was surprised that it was free, but I decided to give it a try anyway. I immediately loved the game after playing through it. This visual novel is well crafted, and is definitely able to make you feel many different emotions throughout its story. 

To start off, I’ll talk about the characters. Normally, I’m one to forget a character or two if there happen to be a lot of them. There are indeed many characters in Lucid9, but they are all extremely memorable for their personalities.  I won’t go into specific details because of spoilers, but every character develops over the course of the game, and it definitely is something that is important for visual novels.

The game’s overall synopsis involves a high school student named Yama Ishimoto in Japan during 2018. Later on, he is asked to be involved in an investigation regarding a chain of disappearances that have occurred at the academy. Again, I won’t spoil in case someone does read this, but the mystery definitely builds up throughout this story. Though it may seem like your choices don’t matter, don’t make this assumption. Lucid9 likes to throw some curve balls to make this visual novel more and more interesting. 

It may seem like this game is only cute, that is not the case, as it transforms into something that contains purpose. It can make you feel happy or apologetic for these characters. You never fully know these characters, and that’s what makes this game different from most visual novels. You think you know everything, but in the end there are still secrets that we don’t know about the characters. The overall plot and ending prove this as you experience it first hand.

Overall, this game makes you laugh at the comical and happy moments, and at other moments, it makes you feel pain and may bring you on the verge of tears (that happened to me at least). If you plan to play the game, it is highly recommended that you play it without any spoilers to fully enjoy the experience that this visual novel offers. Now if you’ll excuse me, I’m going to continue to cry obtaining the achievements in this game.

26474459.review:
Lucid9 is a visual novel. There are not many decisions to be made in this game, and most of them do not really do a lot. Many just let you learn more about other characters, but the romance angle is basically not developed and even the girl you choose will end up rejecting you per se. Most of the choices have to do with certain mystery cases that you need to solve, where there will be one "correct" answer and you will trial and error through all of them before you find it.

I found the art quite charming and the story was interesting. I don't know the developer's fixation with death though. Parents die, siblings die, friends die, friends of friends die, etc. In most cases, I think a murder/death should be a strong element that invokes emotion; but in this case, it happens so often, and it affects so many people that you get desensitized to it. 

I found the character development very good, with the game spanning 13 hours so far for me. The archetypes are fairly typical, but with enough individual flair to keep the reader engaged. The mystery/action sequences are also well done, although I do wish there was a way to skip past them on subsequent playthroughs as it does get rather repetitive.

I did some research and apparently the developers will be putting out the rest of the story (for free!) at some point. The amount of free content here is simply amazing. Well done and can't wait to continue the journey (and to figure out what the name of the game means)!

As a sidebar, if you liked this game, you should check out "One Thousand Lies" - similar art direction and goofy type of dialogue. Also has one of those neat plots where everything comes together at the end too. Free.

If this is your "starter VN" - enjoy! It's cute and quite easy to read. Be sure to check out other visual novels at http://vndb.org after you're done, and welcome to the community!

On the other hand, if you're a VN veteran or simply just played a few of the notorious VNs, you're bound to be annoyed or offended. To say this game borrows from other VNs would be a terrific understatement.
The entire character types and personalities, plot points and even some of the character designs are almost straight out copied out of Devil on G-String with some heavy Kara no Shoujo "inspirations" along the way. I am struggling to find something in this visual novel that is not a complete VN\anime cliche or trope.

Generally, the overall feel of the novel could be described as amateurish, both in writing and art department. I have a constant feeling that the different assets of the novel just don't really work together, with character sprites not really mixing with BGs and struggling to show what the text wants them to. They did nail the UI and fonts perfectly, though, by hiring an outside UI designer, which was a good choice.

Overall, if you can get past all the cliches and "inspirations", you're going to have a pleasant experience, so go ahead, it's not like you're going to lose money trying it out.

I will try to keep spoilers to minimum or even not write any.

I expected this game to be long (in terms of story) and this was the case. As you can see by my playtime it took me over 20 hours to get all the endings and achievements. This is the main reason why this [u]free[/u] game had been sitting on my wishlist for over 5 months. The other reason is that I am not into visual novels lately but once I start reading them I don't stop till I reach the end. Well, I can say I've no regrets.

[h1]Story[/h1]
As I already mentioned for a [u]free[/u] visual novel the story is really long. Not only that but it's really well written. There's variety of words, inversion, puns, no grammar or whatsoever mistakes(?). Not wanting to spoil the story for you I will say that there were moments when I laughed out loud (10+ times?) and other when I cried. The funny thing is I haven't done the latter in years. Literally. You can only guess how touching the story actually was. There are a few plot twists, some of which are really unexpected and I won't be surprised if your jaw drops with your mouth wide open. I will just say that this is not your average they-lived-happily-ever-after novel so prepare to turn into an emotional wreck after reading it (if you're the emotional type that is).

[h1]Characters[/h1]
There are a lot of them. I liked some more than others but I didn't hate/despise any of them. I'd like to mention that they were all very well-drawn (which is truly praiseworthy given the fact that the game is [u]free[/u]) [strike]and I wouldn't mind seeing the waifus in the nude[/strike]. Since the story was so interesting, as if I was part of it, I felt some of the characters really close - like people who you could spend time with or share anything with. Sometimes one of them would say something stupid or odd, or both and that would make me chuckle or even laugh out loud. 

[h1]Music[/h1]
As a muzical addict I've paid attention to the music. If I've said it was great that would be an understatement. Well, it sounded familiar for a moment or two (maybe because the dev(s) have other visual novels that I'd played) but other than that I really enjoyed it. At some parts you will hear the same music that you've heard earlier but it's no surpise since the novel is long. I don't say this as a bad thing, mind you. I want to donate somehow and adding a paid soundtrack DLC seems like a good idea (at least to me).

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I would have written a longer review if I wanted to add spoilers but decided not to. I appologize if I did, if so - it was unintentional. I am glad this game has achievements otherwise I'd have probably skipped it. I am puzzled at how is it even [u]free[/u] given the fact that it takes a good 10+ hours to read the whole story. I've played a lot shorter novels and I'd paid money for them. That's why (as I said) I want to donate if that is possible. I'd already done the same with 3(?) other visual novels that were free. I can't help it. I am a simple man - I read a good [u]free[/u] visual novel, I donate. So do NOT hesitate and give "Lucid9" a try. I assure you that if you're a visual novel fan (not the pls-boobs type) you will have a great time with this one. Since it's [u]free[/u] (did I mention this?) you won't lose anything except maybe some of your time.

25648998.review:
Free. And worth recommending even if it wasn't.
Want a free introduction into the visual novel format that justifies the genre?
It's like getting a really nice eBook or manga for free.


[b][u]Story & Writing[/u][/b]
What has been penned by Fallen Snow's writers is a interesting murder mystery wrapped up in a familiar high school setting in Japan. It starts off in typical tropervile scenarios, but begins to throw things upside down within a few in-story days, with a climatic choice-filled encounter serving as the peak.
Unlike some other VNs, I have never quite felt a need to skip through unread portions of Lucid9 - most of it is engaging. Story has always been a integral part of VNs, and Lucid9 doesn't disappoint.
Writing wise, there are aspects that bug me. Firstly, you can tell that the writing is westernized and English based, despite the setting being in Japan. That's not surprising; Lucid9 is a VN of non-Japanese, international origins.
But when you consider suggestions that the characters are actually conversing in Japanese (strongest hint is that only half-English Elizabeth is billingual), some of the phrases, rhymes, and so on just don't seem like they'll fly in Japanese. But it's not a dealbreaker.
There are also current pop culture references that seem out of place in Japan. 
That said, the story takes some meta jokes that might be silly but are good for laughs anyway. General writing is not overly flowery - it's at a level that is just nice for visual novels.
Then there are all the characters. Each, archetypal at first glance, has at least a decent amount of depth and don't beg you to forget them with their colorful personalities, all lovable.
Choices-wise, Lucid9 is not a kinetic, but [i]Inciting Incident[/i] is the first arc, the "common route", of the story. The ultimate outcome is almost singular, despite your choices, and during the aforementioned climax, there is only one way to succeed (but many variations to failure, ala [i]sound of drop[/i])
[spoiler]The ending for [i]Inciting Incident[/i], however, is a twist. It will polarize. It already has. And I must say that I strongly respect any writer in this genre that has the bravery to make protagonist (who people may not care about) development at the expense of a heroine (who people are very likely to care about). There's a reason this isn't done much.[/spoiler]
What else I can respect is a lack of fan servicey writing or situations throughout Lucid9:II. Perhaps those are reserved for the heroine arcs of the second part, but for now it is nice to see a VN that doesn't need to prop itself up in this way. But bear in mind that this is VN with some dark themes and graphic descriptions of violence. Tread carefully.

Content length? Easily seven hours at minimum, and engaging enough to keep you there nonstop.


[b][u]Artwork[/u][/b]
Lucid9's artwork has a vaguely amateur feel to it. It's not bad, per se, it just feels a bit below the expectations you might harbor if you've seen some of the more famous 'big' works. But then, fate/stay night's original artwork wasn't that professional at the time either, look how that stopped it. [spoiler](it didn't.)[/spoiler]
You can sort of see that the girls, drawn in softer, moe styles, contrast with those of the guys' who are prominently sharper and more defined. There are some mild clashes in art style for the drawn characters, but it's not at all as unnerving as say, Driftwood, another recent free visual novel up here on Steam.
Being more picky, I feel a need to complain about Misaki's alternate poses (where she is facing straight on or holding her phone). Proportionately, they look odd. And her face more so.
Elizabeth's sprites also look awkward from my point of view.
Backgrounds on the other hand, are consistently done well and are not sources of complaint.
As with the story writing, fan service in the artwork is also non-existent. Whether that is a downer or not is up to you, okay? But then, fan disservice is. Bloody scenes are present. You're warned.


[b][u]Sound & Music[/u][/b]
First, I want to sound off that Lucid9 has a pleasantly surprising range of sound effects through out, including the good choice in interface blips. This is a department that some VNs are lacking in these days, especially free ones.
What else is pleasantly surprising, especially for a free-to-play project, is the upcoming inclusion of voice acting (in English).
The music, like the artwork, has a sense of amateurism, but not in the same way as the art. To explain, most if not all the tracks sound like they were made on a home software suite. Which I expect they were. To elaborate, they are not bad compositionally (there are several composers involved here) - some tracks just sound like they were made with rather low end instrument libraries. None sound like they were made with live instruments, and that's not really a surprise, given Lucid9's origins. No, no, it's not a dealbreaker, it's just something I want to point out.
That said, I'd like to hear Miki's theme produced with some new libraries - I like hers particularly.
Which brings me on to the fact that just about every major character appears to have a leitmotif accompanying them, linking to their personalities. Elizabeth has a slightly jazzy piano number with her and Airi has a distinctively music-box like theme.


[b][u]System[/u][/b]
At first glance I didn't think Lucid9 was built on RenPy, though closer examination (and finally a look at the files) confirmed it was. The interface is pretty and the main menu is foreboding, but you can still tell this is RenPy when you notice the "Skip Mode" prompt on the top left and familiar options in the menus.
Unlike other RenPy games though, there is an actual backlog, rather than 'rewinding' when you scroll back, which means you cannot change your mind about a choice you've made unless you've made a save. Which isn't too bad, given the decently large number of save slots (64). I'd appreciate a "return to last choice" function, but again it's not a experience breaker.
Lucid9 also leverages some effects such as 'character zoom' where a currently speaking character's sprite 'moves forward', which is a nice touch. There are also clever manipulations of the interface at critical moments such as flickering text and one of my favorite small touches is the change in color of the interface at the 'darkest' moments.
There are also a couple of moments where you have to enter text to answer a question.



[b][u]Verdict[/u][/b]
FSS has made a visual novel that can definitely stand on its own along other western-origin entries. It's gotten all the necessities right with above average production value among its kind. Which would be true even if it was $10. But it's not - it's free! [b]FREE[/b].

[spoiler]But I still don't understand why it's titled Lucid9. The 9 members of the primary group?
and I'm miffed that Natsuki is not an option in the initial version of best girl poll.[/spoiler]

While it was initially the ratings/reviews and the description (as well as the unbeatable price tag of free) that drew me in, once I started playing there was no turning back. For a variety of reasons.

First though I think it makes sense to give a few reasons to stay away from the game. As of now there is no sequel, and for some that is a major drawback. Later on this will be remedied though. It also lacks diverse, multiple routes and instead has a common route with a variety of potential Bad Endings. Anything else really would be spoiler territory.

For a free game made by developers that created it in their free time, the production value is impressive. Most of the background art and character art is really good, and there are some select examples of really great artwork. Despite a large number of music contributors, the soundtrack feels unified and though the songs range from average to great, their use in creating mood (as well as a lack of music) within the game is tasteful and adds a lot to each scene and every interaction. Its UI is standard and everything works, so no faults to speak of there.

In terms of the actual canon content, the pacing is questionable at times and the characters are a little bit tropey but they all still exhibit their own distinct personalities. Some more than others. Though I understand the reasoning for the balance choice between slice of life and mystery/thriller/horror elements I think that it can be a bit skewed and at times works to the story's disadvantage, but it also makes for some great build-ups and climaxes. Maybe I'm stupid, but the mystery remained a mystery to me up until its reveal, and that was very satisfying to me. Each scene and every "chapter" so to speak flowed well but there are bits that feel like they drag on.

From a more critical perspective the characters are fairly shallow but the plot writing is done well; everything feels like it adds up which isn't easy to do. Thematically it feels hackneyed, processed, and clunky, but despite all of these it never actively took away any notable amount of enjoyment for me. It just didn't add anything. I didn't walk away from it thinking that I had really learned anything, but I did walk away from it knowing that I was looking forward to the next release by Fallen Snow Studios in this series.

[i]Lucid9: Inciting Incident[/i] is a fun and solidly written story boasting impressive audio/visual production and sets up what could be a really interesting story. It still ends very satisfyingly, and I hope that it gets more recognition and that Fallen Snow Studios can follow it up with an equally good or even better product.

I must say that I only decided to pick up this game because it was free and it sounded fairly interesting. After playing it through once, I found it to be an absolute gem, one of those games you just won't know is good until you play it. I'll be honest, my experience with VNs is that I'll often stop a few days before returning to it because I just can't be bothered to keep myself up reading just plain text, but for this game, I just couldn't stop reading, for there is just so much that I love about Lucid9.

First of all, the plot was great and was a crazy roller coaster ride with many ups and downs, even moments I would consider loops and corkscrews. The pacing itself didn't feel rushed to me at all, and additionally, this was JUST the common route and there's so much more to come out for this game in the future. The happy moments in the game were well placed in this relatively serious game, letting you know that while there certainly is a danger present to the characters, they are still students that want to enjoy life and have fun.

The writing was excellent, I especially loved all the references to various anime and games. There's also a little bit of 4th wall breaking, which is always welcome. Everything just flowed really well and often seemed clever.

In regards to the characters, I absolutely loved them. It's not very often that I feel an attachment to characters on this level, they just feel so human and likable. When it comes to Yama, I felt like I could relate to him to some extent, so much so that it felt like I was IN the game every now and then. To me, all these characters are just boasting with personality and just kind of stood out to me. The characters also get a good amount of character development, and as I learned more about each and every single one of them, the more real they seemed.

Music is excellent, it really helps sets to the mood for the events going on in the game.

When it comes to the art, I didn't like it at first, but as I played through it, it just grew on me and I've come to love and appreciate it.

For flaws, It's VERY hard for me to point out any flaws for this game, the experience just felt perfect to me.

Overall, I'd have to say that it is CERTAINLY worth investing all the approximate 10 hours into, and considering it's FREE, there's practically no reason to skip over this game. Honestly, if it wasn't free, I would've thrown money at it, this game was VERY captivating and I had a difficult time putting it down. Even now, after beating it, I'm tempted to go through the whole game again. Please don't let the anime appearance and fairly bountiful amount of girl characters in the game get you thinking that it's just another one of those anime harem dating sims, this game is not what it may appear to be. For the score itself, I just have to give it a solid 10/10, it just isn't possible for me to rate it any lower.

With that, I eagerly await the next part of Lucid9.

It's honestly quite difficult to describe without dropping spoilers, but to put it simply the writers manage to achieve an almost perfect mystery novel voice. [9/10]

Artwork is passable and consistent throughout the playthrough. It won't necessarily dazzle you, but it definitely helps bring the characters to life and backgrounds serve their purpose well enough. [6/10]

The audio is very well done. The soundtrack was definitely my favourite aspect of the game; all of the music, ranging from catchy, upbeat tunes to dark and foreboding ambient tracks really pull you into the protagonist's head, making the immersion all that much better. [10/10]

As a quick side note, the game may present itself as having multiple paths, but in actuality it's fairly linear - good for those of you who don't have a lot of time to spare!

After finishing my playthrough, there's only one aspect of the game I remember disliking. I feel that when the player becomes more knowledgable than the character they play as, it breaks the immersion. It's an obviously necessary mechanism for setting up a sequel, but I feel that just in this one situation the writing could have been better.

23465111.review:
TLDR: The game will draw you in, making you feel something for the characters. By the end, the game rips out your heart. It shows your heart to you. Then it crushes your heart in front of you with just how cruel the reality of the real world can be.

CHARACTERS: 10/10
The characters are actually pretty fun to watch as they interact with each other. There is a shockingly high amount of witty dialogue between most of the characters. Yahiko, the supposedly ever gullible guy who hides his real emotions behind a wall of arrogance and endearing naive attitude. Rui, the witty childhood friend who helped her best friend through a very dark time of his life. Yama, the snarky sarcastic guy with issues who lovingly pokes fun at his friends. Masato, the smart athletic guy who takes most things literally and loves to compete with his friends. Shigure, the independent and intelligent woman who uses her excessively large vocabulary to insult people that piss her off. This is about half of the cast but I won't spoil this treat for people. The characters are memorable and I will not be forgetting them any time soon. The character personalities and their friendships are fleshed out well enough that I see this aspect being, dare I say, believeable. 

MUSIC: 9/10
The accompanying music is actually pretty fitting to the situations that the main character finds himself in. In particular, I really enjoy the title music and the melancholy tracks. When I heard the title music, I suspected that I was in for one hell of a treat when it came to the music. I wasn't fond of the "comedy situation" tracks, hence the 9/10. However, the rest of the tracks made up for that by being very well suited to the themes and situations of the game. Even though there are some parts where there is no music, this doesn't detract from the game at all. The ambient sounds fill the gap rather nicely for almost all of those situations. As for the rest of the situations, the silence works perfectly for driving home specific emotions that are tied directly to the silent scenes.

STORY: 10/10
"Life isn't fair. Deal with it, kid." That sums up the cruelty of this exceedingly well-written story. If you're looking for a lovey-dovey experience that makes your heart feel warm and fuzzy, then you are looking for those things in the wrong game. If you wanna know what the story is about, just read the developer's wall of text in the "About This Game" section. I will say this though: pick your choices wisely or you [i]will die[/i].


MYSTERIES: 9/10
Yes, you are actually pushed into solving mysteries in this game. Don't expect Danganronpa murder mysteries here. However, each mystery is well crafted and it can take some time to figure out the correct answers. Still, the answers are always right in front of you. You just need to adjust your way of thinking from time to time. If you don't have the patience for the mysteries, you can always hit up the Lucid9 guides section. There is a guide that only covers the mysteries. Why take the easy way out when you can give your brain a reasonable challenge?

TWISTS: 8/10
About half-way through the game, I narrowed the murderer down to three suspects. To do that, I literally spent about 30 minutes thinking over all the details that had been discovered in the game. However, the murders aren't the only situations with twists. Sometimes, you think you've got a person figured out and then you find that you are dead wrong. Other times, you think you've got some "friend" of the main character figured out. Then, you notice a little context clue that puts an entire fight between two characters into an ugly context all too similar to real life for some people.

Okay. So this. This is one of the best ELVNs I have ever had the (dis?)pleasure of reading. Hell, let's drop "ELVN" it's up there with some of my favorite VNs in general.

I went into it, skeptical. There are a lot of awful VNs on Steam. Why would this one be different? Sure the reviews were strangely positive, but even so, I went into with a slightly negative attitude and began jeering at characters that I didn't think I'd ever like, at writing I thought was sloppy, at humor I didn't think was funny.

5 hours went by quickly. I was shocked. At some point all those things crumbled and I was thoroughly immersed. I grew to like every character, even the ones I especially expected to hate. The writing had become surprisingly competent, and I grew to love the banter between the characters.

I took a break. Reading it for 5 hours straight was absolutely not my intention. I decided to take a break and finish it the next day.

And I once again got absolutely stuck reading it to completion without a break. Everything just kept getting better and better and worse and worse and finally, I arrived at the ending. Which...wow. And I found out [spoiler]This was merely the common route and that there's more to come?!?![/spoiler] And now, here I am writing this somewhat incoherent review.

I am absolutely blown away. As many others have mentioned this should NOT be free. It is an injustice that this is free when there are so many other laughably awful VNs cluttering Steam that cost money.

Anyway, I love this. And I hate this. 10/10. I absolutely cannot wait to see what Fallen Snow Studios has in store for the future.

22835005.review:
TL;DR: 
Great plot, lively characters, exquisite writing. Better than looks make it seem. If you decide to try this VN out, make sure you actually read the dialog and don't quit just a few hours in to fully absorb the greatness that is Lucid9.

This in-depth review is as spoiler free as possible.

PLOT: 10/10
The first few minutes of the game make you feel like this will be your average visual novel where you choose between different girls and end up dating one of them at the end. Just your normal fluffy waifu simulator. But as the story progresses, the plot goes deeper than you would think.

Even though I was enjoying the light theme of the story at the beginning, I almost stopped playing because I thought that it would only go up to that. Boy, was I glad I didn't stop. This VN is intense, with you trying to make ends meet in your mind as to what is actually happening. If you're reading this, I advise you NOT TO STOP just a few hours in. You won't be able to grasp how well written this story is. But then again, if you're only looking for that fluffy otome style VN, maybe you should turn away.

CHARACTERS: 10/10
I loved the characters in this game. VNs usually only focus on the main girl you are aiming for. This game, on the other hand, lets you get to know all of the characters fairly, as long as you take the time to hang out with them of course. Each character has their own personalities and quirks that make them different from one another. Your relationships with them span from typical childhood friend to idiotic-but-lovable classmate, making your interactions with each of them different. 

WRITING: 9/10
The writing was exquisite. Each character also had their own way of speaking and texting, with varying degrees in their vocabularies. I also loved the details put into this game. By the time you reach the climax, those minor details that you brushed off as insignificant all come flooding back. Those minor bits of foreshadowing all clump together to paint the entire picture. Just lovely.

ART: 8/10
It's your typical anime styled visual novel. It's clean, and the variety of expressions on the characters were good. The backgrounds were pretty as well. The small details like the characters zooming in when speaking worked really well.

MUSIC: 8/10
The background music really ties the feel of the scenes together. It's a great way to set the mood. Happy music for light-hearted scenes, and more solemn music for the more serious parts. Here's hoping that the future voice acting patch helps bring everything together as well. 

OVERALL: 9/10
Very enjoyable, and easy to get hooked on. I can proudly say that my hours spent playing this VN have not gone to waste, especially for a free game. If you have even just a few hours of spare time, I highly recommend giving this game a shot. 
P.S. I enjoyed the various easter eggs and shoutouts to different games. It made me feel that much closer to the characters.

Summary: Free, 10-12 hours of content minimum with multiple endings and a well-developed, intriguing main character.

I really didn't think I'd like this when I downloaded it, but it was free and I had a couple of hours to kill so why not give it a shot anyway..?

Those couple of hours turned into a couple more and then a couple more and ... well, you know how it goes.  The fact is that, even though I thought a relatively passive "visual novel" playstyle was going to bore me, I was engrossed in the story almost from the start.  It's well-written, aside from a few spelling errors here or there (Which initially got me off-side but are, really, quite far and few between), and the character interactions and semi-narration from Yama are fun and, importantly, serve a purpose rather than being inane padding.

There are some choices throughout that impact your end-game result, of which I have seen several.  Which means you'll get more than one playthrough.  Which is amazing, considering that there is already at least 10-12 hours (It depends on how quickly you read, I guess.) of content on the initial playthrough.  For second time round you are given the handy option of fast-forwarding through what you have already read - in case you just want to explore different paths to the end without going through the entire story bit by bit.

The story is nothing gripping or earth-shatteringly new, really, but Yama - whose perspective you are reading from - is well thought out and well written, which is good news because you spend almost every moment with him and his thoughts.  Because of his well-written internal dialogue the supporting characters and, thusly, the story itself becomes intriguing and in turn keeps you reading until the very end.

The background art is simple but effectively conveys setting and the character art is crisp and well-drawn in a typical Manga style which, while nothing new is also not unpleasant.  There is no voice work so it is a hefty amount of reading to put in - perfect for solid or enthusiastic readers although people who need to perhaps be more visually stimulated or distracted by more than just words and simple art may find it difficult to get through the whole thing.

Thoroughly enjoyed my first playthrough and looking forward to seeing the different paths each choice leads to on subsequent replays.
