22486042.review:
Long Story Short: A very good free visual novel. Better than a lot of paid visual novels on steam right now. The first part of a bigger story that manages to resolve its central plot line. If you like visual novels, give it a shot.

Story

Lucid9 follows Yama Ishimoto, a cynical carefree high student of a prestigious high school in 2018 Japan. All is fine with the world, except  it is swiftly shown that students are going missing. The opening scene quickly shows there's a serial killer involved and the central mystery is established.

Inciting Incident is the first part of a larger story and, as such, the romance aspect one may come to expect from visual novels isn't especially present yet. Instead, much of the plot is focused on solving the mystery presented early on, and I believe it has done a good job for this. Yama is neither a super genius or a detective so most of the time he isn't actively trying to solve the puzzle, but the reader, if they stay focused and pay attention, are provided with plenty of clues disguise as typical high school slice-of-life scenes. Having been through the story already, I will say that I believe the mystery is completely fair and can be solved with the information provided directly to the reader.

Characters

Along side the mystery plot are the characters. Yama is quickly shown to be rude, self-centered, snarky and judgemental, most likely far from the expected badass/all-loving/idealistic protagonist one may come to expect from most visual novels. A large number of visual novels will focus on developing the heroines rather than the protagonist and it's refreshing to see a visual novel protagonist with potential for character developments. That said, while it is nice to see someone who's not a straight-up nice guy protagonist, Yama can sometimes be a huge unreasonable, judgemental and unapologetic asshole. So while it's good that the character has a lot of room for development (and he does develop here), Yama can also be very hard to stomach, especially when he gets away with being a huge prick to people who are not his friends. This being a first part of a bigger story however means there's still plenty of time for him to grow out of that, something I look forward to seeing.

Then we have the five heroines: Rui, (blatant) tsundere childhood friend, Elizabeth, high-and-mighty straight-laced overachiever, Akira, bubbly and over-energetic friend, Misaki, quirky and carefree childhood friend and Airi, weird emotionless and literal-minded bullied kid. If you're familiar with visual novels or just anime in general, they will all sound incredibly archetypical. Fortunately, the writing proved to be much better than I initially anticipated, and the girls all have hidden depths that, so far, manages to be believable as well as surprising and avoided being broken birds for the protagonist to fix and woo. The same can also be said to the two male friends: Yahiko, the cheerful idiot, and Masato, the hot-headed stubborn musclehead. It is this unexpected depth that especially impressed me and moved me from eye-rolling at the early parts of the plot to being fully invested in the mystery and development of the characters. That said, it should also be mentioned that a lot of the early dialogues, while not indicative of the strength of the writing, can be so filled with constant sarcasm, snarks and wackiness that they can get very insufferable very quickly. Once you get pass that however, there's a lot to love here and the writing as a whole will prove to be much better than the early stages would suggest.

Gameplay

Lucid9 is a visual novel and come with the sort of gameplay (or whatever you choose to call it) one would expect from the genre. Choices are present. Some are clearly there to let you "earn points" with the respective heroines, some are there for fun, and some are there to test the player's ability to solve the mystery. It is this last set of choices, the one that requires actual deduction, where the game sets itself apart from decision making from more typical visual novels. Of course, considering the mystery questions are boiled down to multiple choice, it removes some of the inherent logic and difficulty in deduction, but nonetheless these sequences are fun brain teasers. That said, there's one sequence late in the game filled with bad ends that most players would likely fail at more than once. The bad ends themselves can be surprising, but they are also very contrived and out of nowhere. This section, I believe, is especially unfair and the trial-and-error that may be required to get through really hampers the tension intended here.

Art and Music

Visually, the game is adequate. It's not the best looking visual novels out there and it's not the worst either. Character designs aren't the best, though that may just be my personal preference, but backgrounds and UI look pretty good for a non-commercial production. The soundtracks serve their purpose and while not many stand out to me personally, there are one or two (especially one used in the ending) that I found very impressive and fitting. At the time of writing, the game has no voice acting. However, the developer promises a free voice patch in the future and samples can be found on the game's website.

Conclusion

Inciting Incident, while a first part of a larger story, manages to conclude its driving mystery while leaving plenty of questions up in the air for the latter parts. That said, the story does end in such a way that more or less demand an immediate follow-up. This coupled with the future voice patch means that right now is perhaps not the best time to start. However, if I am to judge what is present right now on its own merit, I'd say the game is definitely worth getting (and come on it's free). The surprisingly well-written characters and the intriguing and fair mystery sets this above a lot of other paid visual novels and I'd definitely recommend it for any fan of the genre.

This is an emotional rollercoaster of a visual novel that will leave you at the very least happy that you invested your time into it. I hate slice of life. I love mysteries. You know what I really hate? How VN authors always shove slice of life into mystery stories. The slice of life just inevitably clashes with the heavier tone of a good mystery and lessens the suspense. At least, I used to think that such pitfalls were inevitable before reading Lucid9.

Lucid9 takes a while to really get going on the mystery side, instead opting to be predominately lighthearted for the first several hours. Surprisingly though, that actually plays well into the storytelling. In a VN like G-Senjou no Maou, the slice of life scenes, while fun and enjoyable in a vacuum, feel out of place in the larger context of the story. Going from intense crime solving and battles of wits to unconsequential goofy high school funtimes doesn't always work so well. 

However, Lucid9's brilliantly written slice of life (whose brilliance is largely due to hilarious, snappy dialogue) provides some excellent build-up that heightens the impact of the mystery plot later on. When a character is in danger, you actually care. When it comes time to solve the mystery, you really won't want to point fingers at any of the great characters you've come to love. What I'm getting at here is that the slice of life segments do a great job at creating a cast of likable and believable characters that all tie into the plot very nicely.

Of course, even if the slice of life half of the story is strong, the mystery needs to also be good. And it is! The entire story is peppered with subtle foreshadowing that is hidden in plain sight to keep the mystery "fair" to solve, while also being discrete enough that you likely won't know the answers long before their reveals. 22434291.review:
TL; DR Highly enjoyed + recommended, and it's free so it can't hurt to try it out anyway.
Aside from an attention-grabbing mysterious prologue about a psychopathic murderer, Lucid9: Inciting Incident starts off as what may seem like a typical high school slice of life RomCom. Set in the near future of 2018, you have your highly intelligent but seemingly lazy, cynical and snarky male protagonist. You also have the female childhood friend love interest who stuck up for him in the past, helped him get through some past trauma and essentially stick to him like glue his entire life, whilst never actually confessing to him. You even have childhood friend number two, the female transfer student, and let's not forget the protagonist's male allies either;  the apparently aloof, warm-hearted and kind womanizing support character number 1, and support character number 2, the jock (although in his defence his grades are superb). Oh and of course the first female childhood friend has a female friend support character trying to match make the protagonist despite also having feel-
Ok, so you get the idea. As one of the characters say, the protagonist's school life seems like the perfect set up for a 'really crap anime'.
Thankfully, it is anything but.
Despite the initial setup that might send warning signs of a 'cliche', 'boring' or 'generic' environment, the witty dialogue, references, memes and humorous character chemistry create a thoroughly entertaining and amusing experience. The dialogue is spectacular, which is probably partially due to the fact this is an original English story, but to the writers' credit, I'm still surprised by how good the dialogue is.  As you can probably tell, I really enjoyed this section of the game; the protagonist's snarky attitude reminded me of Yuuji from Grisaia with his internal dialogues, and the cutesy art and music meshed together pretty well to create a fun slice of life RomCom. 
Except, of course, that's not what this VN is about. Or at least that's not the main driving force behind the plot. Even throughout this happy-go-lucky style of plot, there is an undercurrent of a darker, more mysterious and dangerous force at work, just in case you didn't notice from the store page screaming murder and mystery at you. And this is where the story really picks up and becomes more about the mystery, murder and detective aspect rather than the high school life of an ordinary student. We see more about the tragic past of the protagonist and his friends, and more foreboding of the murderer's intentions with the chilling music emphasizing the danger as we attempt to deduce who it is. However,  despite the transition into the faster paced plot driven 2nd half of the VN, the focus of the original story is never lost. That is to say, even with all the events in the plot building up climatically to the final showdown, there is always a focus on the main character, his relationships, his past and how he'll change for the better, which I think is a pretty good thing. Because if I had to pick one aspect of the game as a whole that I like the most I'd have to say the characters. Despite what I said about them coming off as generic and cliche at the start of the game, they develop and become fleshed-out, and they seem, believe it or not, human. Which is actually a big deal. They become relatable and pretty damn loveable, which is why they're my favourite part of Lucid9. 
What impresses me the most though is the fact that this is done without any monetary support. To be frank, I was expecting the lack of monetary funding to result in compromises whether it be in the technical elements like the settings/menu options or in the quality of the writing/art/music. But the art style fits the tone, the UI is polished and almost 40 tracks accompany the novel throughout, from the 'nostalgic emotional memory' feel to the 'imminent boss fight' feel, which really does enhance the effect of whatever may be going in the story at that time. For me, I usually place a lot more importance on the writing and art than anything else, but when all the other bits and pieces work, even I can appreciate what a difference they make to the overall quality. 
Another technical element worth highlighting is the choice system, and the interactive aspect of the game in general. Some of the choices give access to new comedic scenes, CG arts or achievements but some of the others are more serious, dictating whether you reach the bad or 'true/good' end. I think a nice balance between difficulty and importance is achieved as a result, because it's pretty easy to either create meaningless choices or give options to a problem that is too tedious to solve by mistake. The few logic puzzles are an enjoyable aspect as they change the pace a bit and force you to think, but at the same time they're definitely accessible, and if you choose the wrong answer or the joke answer you're easily forgiven too. I'm eager to see more of them in the future since I suspect they will become more common in the individual heroine routes when the fundamental mystery plot is actually revealed.  
I suppose the one gripe I have is that a technical feature that I think could be implemented is missing; a skip to the next choice feature, mostly for replaying + achievement/cg hunting. Personally I've never been that much of an achievement collector but I admit I get curious if I see a bunch of hidden achievements and missing CG art, enough to want to select the choices I didn't choose last time and see what happens. A skip to the next choice feature would help in that regard, rather than just using the ordinary skip function whilst making a lot of save points at all the choices.
Overall though, I'm pretty damn impressed by Lucid9. I'll definitely be looking forward to both the voice patch and the heroine route patch, since this is only the beginning after all. This is easily in my top 6 VNs, and to be honest, if you've gotten this far in the review and still aren't sure whether to try it or not, just do it. It's free after all.

May I add that it never overstays its welcome, either. If there's something funny but fast being commented on, then the response in narration is short, snappy, and funny. If it's serious, you bet it'll switch to longer panel/novel sections to describe it. As aforementioned, I feel the balance is on point. It feels like conversation and thoughts in real life.

You may being seeing these cutesy anime waifus and pretty bishounen anime husbandos being like, "ugh, I bet SHE'S gonna be all uguu kawaii desuuuuUUUU," or, "ugh, I bet the protagonist is gonna be ALL ABOUT that harem lifestyle!" No. Please. Please let me tell you that the characters are some of the most three-dimensional that I've ever seen. I can relate to many of the things the protagonist says, and can honestly feel like he... is human. He feels so human. And others around him feel human, too. Also believe me when I say they know what they're talking about here; these writers have knowledge in the cliches and tropes and popular trends of anime, pop culture, technology, and society when considering their characters and their interests, etc; they parody it frequently. I prefer the male character art as opposed to the female style in this, but it's definitely right for those who want their cute waifus! The menus already (really, the title) can give off the tone this game wants to set and stays consistent all throughout. These 9 hours I have poored in definitely do stay comedic, but it almost feels like they want you to know what you're getting into. By the time you hit 'start,' you'll have an idea. The in-game menus (save, load, quit, etc.) are also much more effective than your usual visual novel. They are shortened to just icons in the corner of the screen and take up virtually no space so that the writing is put on the spotlight always.

THE MUSIC AND SOUND IS WELL-COMPOSED, CATCHY, AND VERY ATMOSPHERIC. The music the moment I got into the title screen is good, and again, sets a very specific... tone. The tracks are not too repetitve in my opinion unless your patience is short, and some of the more dramatic tracks are still on my brain right now. I'm no sound effects specialist or anything, but the sound effects are also very good. Please play with headphones on! The sounds of passing footsteps going from ear to ear is honestly lovely to hear as a touch.

THIS IS A FREE VISUAL NOVEL, BY THE WAY. IT'S FREE, and it goes FAR beyond my expectations for what a free visual novel usually contains. I have not gazed upon such a beauty of a visual novel in a very long time, especially being free. Have I mentioned that it's free? 

IF I HAD ONE CRITICISM, it might be the... setting. All of this feels particularly strange being set in Japan. TL;DR: Long, in depth review. Extremely well executed plot. Deep, flawed, very loveable, human like characters. Nice art (I'm too dumb to tell more than that). Notable BGM and some very polished minor details. FREE. FREE FREE FREE. Go play it.

Warning though: INTENSE.



FULL REVIEW:

I went into this game figuring I'd play it a little bit at a time. It looked ok enough, at least.

I marathoned it pretty much in one sitting. Skipped class to do it, too. It's THAT good. Even if you don't like the whole anime subculture, give it a shot. It dodges or parodies a lot of the cliches and presents a deep, thought provoking, and emotionally powerful story. If you DO like the anime subculture, you'll probably like it even more.

There's so much to be said about it... What a rollercoaster. 

Very mild spoilers below; I won't discuss specific events, but I might mention themes and such. Anything I say you can figure out from the description of the game.


PLOT:

It seems like a nice, innocent little setting. High school, cute girls, blah blah slice of life.

It's not.

This is not to take away from the first part of the game; I enjoyed it. It was funny. About one third to half way through the story, though the plot gets more and more intense. It transitions from "cute and enjoyable" to "powerful and meaningful."

The climax is absolute insanity; it's horrifically disturbing yet simultaneously exhilirating, fueled all the more by the sudden influx of decisions you have to make. Everything is connected very logically and coherently, however. It's not some random shift that leaves you scratching your head wondering how you got there. It's an inevitable build up that leaves you both anticipating and dreading your arrival at that point. The contrast between the first and last parts of the game really emphasize a feeling of breakdown. 

More generally, the plot is extremely well constructed and paced. It never felt too fast or too slow, which is probably why it managed to retain my horribly short attention span for such a long period. It flows really well too, where one event easily leads into the next. The actual events of the plot are good, but nothing spectacular, but the way it's executed makes it fantastic. 

I loved the whole thing. Laughed like an idiot almost nonstop at the copious wit and comedy, raged at the insanity, cried when appropriate. It's an absolute rollercoaster, but so worth the ride. 

Fair warning, though. It gets REALLY intense. And it really hurts sometimes. I liked the pain though. 
If I have any complaint, it's that there were some plot points that I found disatisfying, as a player. I understand why they were made though. That doesn't mean I have to be happy about it. Lucid 9 unappolgetically proposes some very difficult themes and sticks to them. It's a story that has meaning.

The rest of the game HAS to come or I'll cry for real. 


CHARACTERS:

My favorite part of any story. If I don't like the characters, I don't read. Simple as that.

Lucid 9 has really, really good characters.

While they're obviously based on common anime archetypes, Lucid 9's characters transcend the cliches on which they were born. They're nuanced, fleshed out, very flawed, and so, so lovable. They feel very human and complex, in a way that almost no other anime or game I've seen has managed. You won't always agree with them. Actually, a lot of the time, you probably won't. But they're all the better for it. And most of the time, you'll laugh and cry with them anyways. Just don't try to write yourself into the story or expect them to be perfect. This ain't no utopia. 

Also, the girls are cute. And the guys. So if you don't care about any of the stuff I just spouted, at least there's that.


WRITING:

The writing is super smooth; this is very clearly a game that was originally written in english, not translated. I'm kind of a prose nerd, and some of the phrases gave me chills. The word-art is every bit as well done as the visual-art. 

It's also hilarious and amazingly witty, especially in the beginning. At the end, when everything goes nuts, nothing feels cheesy, which is quite a feat in emotional scenes. I'm a very critical reader, but I had no issues with the writing. 10/10

Oh, and Gover Mecher is genius. Funniest satirical parody. 


ART:

It's pretty. I like it. Sorry, I have the artistic talent of a brick. Go look at the pictures. You'll know if you like it or not.


MUSIC:

I don't notice the BGM in most games, but Lucid 9's really stood out to me for some reason. It manages to be catchy and noteworthy without overbearing, enough so that I felt inclined to include it as a seperate section.


OTHER:

There are plenty of little things that make the game feel very polished and add a lot to the atmosphere. Simple things like phone animations, ocassional game-esque overlays, and flashing or faded UI contribute heavily to a scene without being ostentatious. It's not stuff I would have thought of, but there are some scenes that I can't imagine without them.


VERDICT: 

Excellent game. Deep, provactive, but fun and enjoyable. I read through it in one sitting and I don't even like VNs. Those of you brave souls that DO will probably like it even more.  

Also, it's free. FREE. With far better production value than most commercial stories. You legit have nothing to lose. Except time, I guess. Which most of us will probably waste in worse ways anyways. 

Did I mention it's FREE?
